habitat_description:
The range encompasses the region of southeastern California, southern Arizona, New Mexico, southern Kansas, Oklahoma, and Texas. In Mexico, it occurs from the north into Zacatecas, south into northern Vercaruz. From southern Mexico, populations extend into Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica (Rossman et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003).

Known to burrow in or using soil, leaf litter, and logs. When not hiding, this species is found in creeks, medium sized rivers, springs, and various shallow water bodies. In addition, habitats include riparian zones, desert, cropland, hardwood forest, hardwood woodland, grassland, chaparral, savanna, and shrubland. Reports include orchards and other suburban areas (Natureserve.org). In general, this species is mostly common in lowland habitats (Degenhardt et al. 1996). In southern Texas, the checkered gartersnake is generally found in backyards, gardens, thornbrush savanna, flooded areas, swamps, and irrigation ditches (Rossman et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003; Werler and Dixon 2000). The habitats in southern Mexico and Central America are characterized by pine-palmetto savanna, and tropical wet, dry, and moist forest (Campbell 1998; Lee 2000).


Occupies areas of chaparral, shrubland, and various woodland type habitats that usually provide dense clumps of vegetation as cover. The habitats where this species is most common, wet and high humidity conditions increase the amount of cover provided for this species in riparian zones.
